    • Prerequisites
    • 1. Ingest a Dataset
      • Object Relational Model (ORM)
      • a) Registering Datasets
        • Dataset.Tabular
        • Dataset.Sequence
        • Dataset.Image
      • b) Reading Datasets into Memory
        • Dataset.Tabular
        • Dataset.Sequence
        • Dataset.Image
    • 2. Selecting Features and Labels.
      • a) Select the Label column(s).
        • ORM
        • Deriving Labels
        • Reading Labels
      • b) Select the Feature column(s).
        • ORM
        • Specifying Features
        • Reading Features
    • 3. Slicing samples.
      • a) Define sliding time series Windows.
        • ORM
        • Specifying Windows
        • Reading Windows
      • b) Slice samples with a Splitset.
        • Stratification
        • Splitting Strategies
        • Reading Splitsets
      • c) Create a Foldset for cross-validation.
        • ORM
        • Fold objects
        • Specifying Foldsets
        • Reading Foldsets
    • 4. Preprocessing - Interpolation.
      • ORM
      • a) Interpolate Labels with Labelpolater.
      • b) Interpolate Features with Interpolaterset.
    • 5. Preprocessing - Encoding.
      • Encoding
      • a) Encode labels with Labelcoder.
        • Creating a Labelcoder
      • b) Encode Features sequentially with Ensoderset.
        • Filtering feature columns
    • 6. Preprocessing - Reshaping.
      • ORM
      • Reshaping by Index
      • Reshaping Explicitly
      • Multiplicative Reshaping
    • 7. Defining Architectures & Hyperparameters.
      • a) Define an Algorithm
        • Model Definition
        • Group the functions together in an Algorithm!
      • b) Combinations of hyperparameters with Hyperparamset.
        • Hyperparameter Selection Strategies.
        • Hyperparamcombo objects.
    • 8. Queue of training Jobs.
      • a) Job objects.
      • b) Executing Jobs.
        • i) queue.run_jobs()
        • ii) DEPRECATED - queue.run_jobs(in_background=True).
        • iii) Future, cluster execution.
      • c) Predictors are the trained models.
        • Fetching the trained model.
      • d) Predictions are the output of a Predictor.
        • Fetching metrics.
    • 9. Metrics & Visualization
  • Inference
    • Predictor

  • Keras: Tabular Classify Multi-Label
  • View page source

Keras: Tabular Classify Multi-Label

Categorizing Plant Species with Multi-Label Classification of Phenotypes.

[2]:

import aiqc
from aiqc import datum

import keras
from keras.models import Sequential
from keras.layers import Dense, Dropout
from keras.callbacks import History
from sklearn.preprocessing import OneHotEncoder, StandardScaler

Example Data

Reference Example Datasets for more information.

[3]:

df = datum.to_pandas('iris.tsv')

[4]:

df.head()

[4]:
sepal_length sepal_width petal_length petal_width species
0 5.1 3.5 1.4 0.2 setosa
1 4.9 3.0 1.4 0.2 setosa
2 4.7 3.2 1.3 0.2 setosa
3 4.6 3.1 1.5 0.2 setosa
4 5.0 3.6 1.4 0.2 setosa 
[5]:

df.dtypes

[5]:

sepal_length    float64
sepal_width     float64
petal_length    float64
petal_width     float64
species          object
dtype: object

a) High-Level API

Reference High-Level API Docs for more information including how to work with non-tabular data.

[6]:

splitset = aiqc.Pipeline.Tabular.make(
    # --- Data source ---
    df_or_path = df
    , dtype = None

    # --- Label preprocessing ---
    , label_column = 'species'
    , label_interpolater = None
    , label_encoder = dict(sklearn_preprocess = OneHotEncoder())

    # --- Feature preprocessing ---
    , feature_cols_excluded = 'species'
    , feature_interpolaters = None
    , feature_window = None
    , feature_encoders = dict(
        sklearn_preprocess = StandardScaler()
        , dtypes = ['float64']
    )
    , feature_reshape_indices = None

    # --- Stratification ---
    , size_test = 0.22
    , size_validation = 0.12
    , fold_count = None
    , bin_count = None
)


=> Info - System overriding user input to set `sklearn_preprocess.sparse=False`.
   This would have generated 'scipy.sparse.csr.csr_matrix', causing Keras training to fail.


=> Info - System overriding user input to set `sklearn_preprocess.copy=False`.
   This saves memory when concatenating the output of many encoders.


___/ featurecoder_index: 0 \_________

=> The column(s) below matched your filter(s) featurecoder filters.

['sepal_length', 'sepal_width', 'petal_length', 'petal_width']

=> Done. All feature column(s) have featurecoder(s) associated with them.
No more Featurecoders can be added to this Encoderset.

Reference this great blog for machine learning cookbooks: MachineLearningMastery.com “Multi-Label Classification”.

[7]:

def fn_build(features_shape, label_shape, **hp):
    model = Sequential()
    model.add(Input(shape=features_shape))
    model.add(Dense(units=hp['neuron_count'], activation='relu', kernel_initializer='he_uniform'))
    model.add(Dense(units=label_shape[0], activation='softmax'))
    return model

[8]:

def fn_train(model, loser, optimizer, samples_train, samples_evaluate, **hp):
    model.compile(
        loss = loser
        , optimizer = optimizer
        , metrics = ['accuracy']
    )
    model.fit(
        samples_train["features"]
        , samples_train["labels"]
        , validation_data = (
            samples_evaluate["features"]
            , samples_evaluate["labels"]
        )
        , verbose = 0
        , batch_size = hp['batch_size']
        , epochs = hp['epoch_count']
        , callbacks=[History()]
    )
    return model

[9]:

hyperparameters = {
    "neuron_count": [9, 12]
    , "batch_size": [3]
    , "learning_rate": [0.03, 0.05]
    , "epoch_count": [30, 60]
}

[10]:

queue = aiqc.Experiment.make(
    # --- Analysis type ---
    library = "keras"
    , analysis_type = "classification_multi"

    # --- Model functions ---
    , fn_build = fn_build
    , fn_train = fn_train
    , fn_lose = None #auto
    , fn_optimize = None #auto
    , fn_predict = None #auto

    # --- Training options ---
    , repeat_count = 1
    , hyperparameters = hyperparameters
    , pick_percent = None

    # --- Data source ---
    , splitset_id = splitset.id
    , foldset_id = None
    , hide_test = False
)

[11]:

queue.run_jobs()

🔮 Training Models 🔮: 100%|██████████████████████████████████████████| 8/8 [00:49<00:00,  6.21s/it]

For more information on visualization of performance metrics, reference the Visualization & Metrics documentation.

b) Low-Level API

Reference Low-Level API Docs for more information including how to work with non-tabular data, and defining an optimizer.

[12]:

dataset = aiqc.Dataset.Tabular.from_pandas(df)

[13]:

label_column = 'species'

[14]:

label = dataset.make_label(columns=[label_column])

[15]:

labelcoder = label.make_labelcoder(
    sklearn_preprocess = OneHotEncoder(sparse=False)
)

[16]:

feature = dataset.make_feature(exclude_columns=[label_column])

[17]:

encoderset = feature.make_encoderset()

[18]:

featurecoder_0 = encoderset.make_featurecoder(
    sklearn_preprocess = StandardScaler()
    , dtypes = ['float64']
)


___/ featurecoder_index: 0 \_________

=> The column(s) below matched your filter(s) featurecoder filters.

['sepal_length', 'sepal_width', 'petal_length', 'petal_width']

=> Done. All feature column(s) have featurecoder(s) associated with them.
No more Featurecoders can be added to this Encoderset.


[19]:

splitset = aiqc.Splitset.make(
    feature_ids = [feature.id]
    , label_id = label.id
    , size_test = 0.22
    , size_validation = 0.12
)

[20]:

def fn_build(features_shape, label_shape, **hp):
    model = Sequential()
    model.add(Dense(units=features_shape[0], activation='relu', kernel_initializer='he_uniform'))
    model.add(Dropout(0.2))
    model.add(Dense(units=hp['neuron_count'], activation='relu', kernel_initializer='he_uniform'))
    model.add(Dense(units=label_shape[0], activation='softmax'))
    return model

Optional, just included to show users how to specify their own optimizer.

[21]:

def fn_optimize(**hp):
    optimizer = keras.optimizers.Adamax()
    return optimizer

[22]:

def fn_train(model, loser, optimizer, samples_train, samples_evaluate, **hp):
    model.compile(
        loss = loser
        , optimizer = optimizer
        , metrics = ['accuracy']
    )
    model.fit(
        samples_train["features"]
        , samples_train["labels"]
        , validation_data = (
            samples_evaluate["features"]
            , samples_evaluate["labels"]
        )
        , verbose = 0
        , batch_size = hp['batch_size']
        , epochs = hp['epoch_count']
        , callbacks=[History()]
    )
    return model

[23]:

algorithm = aiqc.Algorithm.make(
    library = "keras"
    , analysis_type = "classification_multi"
    , fn_build = fn_build
    , fn_train = fn_train
)

[24]:

hyperparameters = {
    "neuron_count": [9, 12]
    , "batch_size": [3]
    , "learning_rate": [0.03, 0.05]
    , "epoch_count": [30, 60]
}

[25]:

hyperparamset = algorithm.make_hyperparamset(
    hyperparameters = hyperparameters
)

[26]:

queue = algorithm.make_queue(
    splitset_id = splitset.id
    , hyperparamset_id = hyperparamset.id
    , repeat_count = 1
)

[27]:

queue.run_jobs()

🔮 Training Models 🔮: 100%|██████████████████████████████████████████| 8/8 [00:30<00:00,  3.82s/it]

For more information on visualization of performance metrics, reference the Visualization & Metrics documentation.
